Napoleon Total War is a Tactical Wargame set in the Napoleonic Wars. That is why Napoleon Bonaparte is in it. Made by Creative Assembly ages ago, it was the first game I had, and the ultimate reason I ever got Steam. 3 years later it is still among my favourite games, and I still play it - though to a much higher quality than I used to.   Set in the Napoleonic Wars, as stated above, the main Campaign covers Napoleon’s Campaigns in Italy, Europe, Egypt, and the Peninsular. You are put in command of the French army, and in a certain amount of turns, must complete the campaign ending in a French victory. These campaigns are fun to play, and it feels good to replicate Napoleon's later military career, slaying his foes on the field, though I must be honest I do not think it is the best part of the game.   Alternatively, if you do not want to play as the French, there is the 'Campaigns of the Coalition' option where you can play as any one of the 5 military superpowers of the era. Those being France, ♥ Great Britain ♥, Austria, Prussia, and Russia. Depending what type of campaign you play, they vary in length and difficulty, but you must strategically put your foes to the sword in your best efforts to meet all of your objectives, thus making your nation the very best it can be. Elite not only in Military and Navy, but also economy, and technological advancements. I wrote a campaign  guide  (For Great Britain) which you can view here, showing and explaining in more detail what you can do in a Campaign, and things that may aid you, such as Spies, Gentlemen and of course your control over the Government, and how to use them effectively.   Napoleon really stands out from all other Total War titles in its battles, which are extremely well made. While I do not like many of the maps, and wish perhaps there could have been more, for the most part, games both multiplayer and single player require a lot of strategy and logic to win. There are varying difficulties, though with some experience, the AI soon becomes too easy for everyone, but each demand a more thoughtful approach to the tactic you use in order to ensure your ultimate victory. I've also made a guide on how I fight  battles , again as Great Britain. It was made a while ago, but my tactic hasn't really changed. Sorry if it's written badly in places, but I didn't want to edit it for memorabilia :D   This is my opinion, and many don't agree, but I believe Napoleon was the best Total War game. It's interface is simple and easy to use, but effective too, while still looking good. Graphically I think it walks all over the likes of Shogun 2 and Rome II, despite is age in comparison to the two. The combat engine is good, and fights, both shooting and melee, are fun to watch. The only criticism I do have are its musket sounds. They are quite bad, but this doesn't ruin the feel of the game.   Another reason I am so fond of this game is undeniably the era. I really like the Napoleonic wars, and oddly enough this game sparked my love for it three years ago, and so, to me, there is not another Total War like it. I've no interest in Roman or Medieval history, so perhaps my high opinion of it is partly because of that.   Overall, it is a great game. It's few small floors such as men charging the wrong way, and infantry not forming square in time for cavalry can be annoying, but they don't kill the game for me. I would give this game a proud 9.5/10. It's Creative Assembly's best work, and since then it's on a steady downhill decline for me, with their terrible interfaces and annoying camera restrictions in games such as Shogun 2 and Rome II, but that's for another review.   Thank you for reading my review :)

Well with just over 109 hours of my life playing this game, I can indeed recommend this to those who enjoy a late Sunday afternoon of killing the french and laughing with your English friends, but all jokes aside.   Napoleon: Total war is a game that has a level of strategy that will cause even the best of the game series to sit down and think of their next step in overthrowing their opponent.   Many of you who read this will know that Napoleon: Total war isn't the first of its kind, as you already know that the Total war series takes you to different time periods, pushing the player into different scenarios that will test the player's skill to direct his/her army to victory, by any means necessary.   In Napoleon: Total war, you fight against the AI in some well done (short) campaigns. But the real meat of this game is the online aspect. Sadly, not many people play this gem, as they say, that Empire: Total war was the better of this time period. I will decline their opinions and state, that Napoleon sits in favour of my taste. The game does better to sit you in the midst of the battles, not only reducing the factions you can choose from but giving them a bit of their own flavour and the diverse nations to bring their own types of units (Up to a max of 20) into battle to take own another player, whom has most likely just chosen their favourite faction that they always play with.   Many probably won't believe me, many won't care. But Napoleon: Total war is easy to pick up, but hard to get good at (Not a hard learning curve). Because at every turn, someone will surprise you, whether it be a sudden and devastating surprise attack at the rear, or maybe they have decided to lure you in, only to bring in the good units at the last moment to seize the day. No matter your play style, you will find someone (Mainly if they have better than 3 stars) that will put up a challenge and make you feel like a general, fighting your own battle and making your own tale of glory.   Oh and it has a turn-based campaign, but nobody really plays that. If you want to play the campaign, go get Medieval 2 or Shogun 2.

After putting in over 30 hours into this wonderfully crafted strategy game during the era of the Napoleonic Wars I can say for sure without a doubt that any tactically player or historical player will LOVE this game! Imagine managing any one of the multiple major nations at the time such as Russia or Britain, allowing you to make any decision from controlling your government, trade, industry, research, diplomacy and of course your most important is your military. Now not only are you given objectives to complete within a certain time period but also it gives you the chance for European domination as any one of those major nations. Plan your nation's expansion across Europe allowing you to pick any strategy possible from either destroying large nations to annexing smaller nations into your unstoppable empire! Once you're tired of playing Napoleon's 3 campaigns (Italy, Egypt, and Europe) you can play as any of the coalition nations against Napoleon's France or play multiple different battles that were decisive turning points in history from The Battle of Waterloo to The Battle of the Nile. Finally once you've completed all of that there is multiplayer that is quite entertaining when playing campaigns or battles with friends or anyone else too. Overall this is a pretty good Total War game to buy for you and a friend to play sometime together as a team or as foes.

You don't see a battle. You *hear* it. Black powder blasting by the ton on all sides. Black smoke blinding you and choking you and making you vomit. Then the French come out of the smoke - not in a line, but in a column. And they march towards our thin line, kettledrums hammering like hell and a golden eagle blazing overhead. They march slowly, and it takes them a long time to reach you, and you can't see them in smoke. But you can hear the drums. They march out of the smoke, and you fire a volley. And the front rank of the column falls, and the next rank steps over them, with drums hammering, and the column smashes your line like a hammer breaking glass... and Napoleon has won another battle.

Truly a great addition to the Total War series. It looks beautiful, the music is hauntingly solemn--which is rather fitting for a game that teaches you how absolutely worthless human life actually is--and it's just an all-around fantastic game. My only complaint is the smaller size of the campaign, though I guess I was kind of spoiled by how extensive Rome II and Empire's campaigns were.  Also, a spy of mine stumbled into a French border town, and Napoleon just happened to be there. He had a 20% chance of assassinating the face of France himself, so I just kinda shrugged and gave him the order to do it, and he ♥♥♥♥in' succeeded. Napoleon was dead before the first year of the game was over. 10/10, would change the course of history again.

This is certainly my favorite total war game to date. It features several different campaigns that take from the beginning to the end of the prestigious general's career. If your computer is capable, the visuals are gorgeous, especially once the combat starts and smoke covers the field and blows in the wind. The AI is decent for a total war game, and much better than Empire's AI, which could never seem to correctly fight line battles. I love how tactical the gameplay can get, and this total war emphasizes on positioning and formation to win battles, not just charging everything in sight. There have been several instances in custom and multiplayer battles when my smaller or less experienced force defeated a much more powerful army simply by being in better formation, and I love that. I feel like each unit in this game is useful and can succeed when commanded well. The game itself is crisp and clean and relatively bug free, and local multiplayer games have been a blast. I highly recommend this game to anyone interested in the time period or fans of the total war games, particularly empire due to the simularities. What I expected to be merely a $15 mod for Empire total war turned out to be a much more polished and enjoyable game all around.

The game is essentially Empire without the crippling bugs and more tasty unit variety. Where in Empire, most of the mainstay European faction units were painfully generic, thankfully there's much more unit types and looks now.  The main campaign is a close knit and somewhat scripted affair, it doesn't detract from the experience, as you are retracing Napoleon's footsteps. If that doesn;t strike your fancy, there's also Campaignsof the Coalition in which it is more open ended but still on a smaller map than empire, plotting Napoleon's downfall.  It's not entirely historically accurate, an inevitability in such a game like this. However, it tries its best to stick to period authentic tactics and effects.  The battle effects are very lovely to look at although the Warscape engine is starting to show cracks what with wonky animation sync and sound clipping as well as some atrocious balance in some engagements. However, it works and is a decent engine for representing Napoleonic combat.  I am a bit biased as I am a monumental Napoleonic and 18th century history enthusiast and if you have a love of history or total war or any other strategy 4x title, I recommend this game highly.  Tl;DR thank god it isn't Rome II.

Another Gaius Julius Ceasar review  Before i lost my original steam account and deleted the email attached because it was always spamming my email with mailer demon, resulted in me losing my only way to regain my old steam account this game and shogun 2 were the only steam games i had.  However though this is not a 100% like, it is more a 57% like, the game has great things to say but at the same time it also has it's downfalls.    Lets start with the upsides first.   The game is very good for it's diplomacy, it seperates the minor factions from the major and allows for regions to be swaped, unlike in Rome II, state gifts can be given and trade embargos can be broken via diplomacy. This allows for a really great political feel that i believe is missing a bit in ROME II.  The factions are powerfull and most off them are allies, this allows for much more ease of mind, knowing that you will not be facing a war on all fronts.   The graphics is good, it has a great campaign graphics.   Now for some of the downfalls:   As I mentioned above the graphics are good, great campaign graphics but terrible battle graphics, this is a major downfall because you need to get up close and wait a few seconds before you can see the soldiers as normal instead of a weird blurred shape thing.   Also as mentioned before, in the coalition ( which for me is the whole campaign ) you are allied with nearly every country that bonaparte is not in control of. This can be good for an ease of mind but also makes it annouyingly difficult to expand at all, because if you are playing as say Austria then you cannot invade RUSSIA, PRUSSIA, this prevents great expansion, the only true places Austria can invade is the ottoman empire or the italian steas, and France. If not for Shogun 2 I would call this the best Total War game, sans mods.  It's got a great set of unit counters and all the nations have really distinct units and strategies despite the age of horse and cannon often seeming too simple. The strategies you can use are immense, the campaign map is incredibly detailed and rewarding despite only covering Europe, and it's very pretty and well-optimized. The game rewards you for securing trade routes, for harassing your enemy, for having good plans, and for ambushing.  The only negative is that the siege warfare is pretty much redundant in this game since forts are so ridiculously powerful that they're almost impossible to take if the enemy has anywhere near your numbers.  Most importantly, it has much better unit variety and almost no bugs compared to it's awful predecessor, Empire.  If you're a Total War fan GET IT. If you're not a Total War fan and you want a relatively complex and deep 18-19th century wargame with an incredible amount of freedom compared to other games of it's type, here's your title.

A interesting game of the Napoleonic Era in history. Another game in the Total War Series. The game is similiar to Empire: Total War However, all the attention in terms of land warfare is focused entirely on the European continent. Just like in Empire: Total War there are Sea Trade routes to get to using trade ships while building Warships for protection, raiding, invading, and blockading ports. The trade routes are on the western part of the game map in the Atlatic Ocean, the Mediterranean Sea, and even the Black Sea. In Napoleon: Total War you can take the lessons from Empire: Total War and apply them. Will you be one of the greatest strategiest in history Napoleon Bonaparte of France the 2nd AntiChrist (Depending on how you view Napoleon Bonaparte) and conquer all of Europe, or will you be one of the major powers of the time (Great Britian, Austria, Prussia, or Russia) fighting against Napoleon's France and then turning on your Allies to achieve your Victory conditions if need be? How will you create your alternative history in the Napoleonic Era?

I'm loving the units set in the Napoleontic era; artillery becomes useful but it's still possible to achieve a complete victory on the battlefield using mobile units (fast moving soldiers or mounted units). Either way, it has given me more than its money's worth of entertainment!

10/10 Would fight in the shadows of the Pyramids again!  Napoleon is huge improvement from Empire, essentially, the battles are now more naturally paced and feel very player influenced. Artillery is the biggest asset in the game, using the battle of Arcole for example, holding a bridge and firing at it with canister shot is often the deal breaker.   Cavalry takes a backseat to Artillery, but its still effective, dragging heavily armored mounted units through light infantry will destroy them. Infantry is the last in importance, however; line infantry is more durable, but less spammable as they lack the range to attack longer ranged infantry blocks effectively.  Essentially, the best part of each battle in the later stages, because your going to lack fully stocked infantry. Your going to find that victory is often due to tactical play, rather than spamming line infantry and rushing people down.

Arm-chair General on steroids. A brilliant, near perfect adaptation of the 19th century European battlefield (commonly known as Napoleon's playground). While the single-player in the Total: War series has evolved through each title, it has in a sense become a forgotten art that the multiplayer portion desperately, and lusciously makes up for. As a history aficionado, it has fast-seduced my temporal-lobes in a way that can only be described as enjoyable. My only quibble is that the United States wasn't included--have we all forgotten the great Louisiana Purchase? C'mon man!  I don't always play France, but when I do--I prefer enlisting Prussia.
